container-title: Current FIPS related to cryptography include: • FIPS PUB 140-2: Security Requirements for Cryptographic Modules. • FIPS PUB 180-4: Secure Hash Standard (SHS). • FIPS PUB 186-4: Digital Signature Standard (DSS). • FIPS PUB 197: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES). • FIPS PUB 198-1
title: Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) – These computer security and crypto-related FIPS PUBs are produced by the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) as standards for the US Government

American National Standards Institute. US-based organization that, among other activities, develops standards for telecommunications
Direct sequence spread spectrum or spectral spread by a direct sequence
Exterior Gateway Protocol. Protocol used between routers of different systems
It is an interconnection architecture for local networks, a set of layers that provides the encapsulation of frames, before being sent to the network
European Telecommunications Standards Institute
Extended validation secure socket layer. Advanced or extended validation SSL certificate
Malicious program designed to exploit a computer or program’s vulnerability
Federal Communications Commission. US government agency responsible for regulatory issues in the telecommunications area
Local multipoint distribution system. Fixed wireless system used for voice and data transmission

container-title: MIPS – Millions of instructions per second
title: Frequency unit that equates to 106 Hz
Multimedia message service. Technology used in cellular telephony for the transmission of data, such as text, image, audio, and video

Mobile broadband – Type of broadband connection. Wireless long distance access technology through a mobile phone network, especially 3G and 4G (respectively the third and fourth generation of mobile telephone standards defined by the International Telecommunication

MOdulator and DEModulator. Equipment that converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted by physical means, such as telephone lines, pay-TV cable, or fiber optics
Motion Picture Experts Group. Organizations which, among other things, define standards for video signals
Most significant bit. Binary digit in the most significant position of the binary word
Equipment that combines several signals to be transmitted on a single transmission channel

container-title: Network scanning – Technique that consists of performing thorough searches on networks, with the objective of identifying active computers Glossary of Information Security Terms 259
title: Set of standards of conduct for Internet users, defined in the document “RFC 1855: Netiquette Guidelines
Public switched telephone network (PSTN
Quality of service. Parameter used to measure the quality of various functions of a communication network
Research and Development for Advanced Communications. European committee for the creation of advanced communication networks
This protocol is to allow a permanent memory computer to have an IP address starting from its Ethernet address
Switched network, X.25 standard, used in Brazil in the 1970s
RIP Routing Information Protocol dynamically updates routing tables over WANs and the Internet. The distance vector algorithm is used to calculate the best route for the packet
Security incident – Any adverse event, confirmed or suspected, related to the security of computer systems or computer networks
Internet site identified by a domain name, consisting of one or more hypertext pages, which may contain text, graphics, and multimedia information
Site shielding – Service package that identifies and corrects website vulnerabilities
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol. Protocol responsible for transporting e-mail messages on the Internet
Traffic interception
Glossary of Information Security Terms
Traffic interception – Technique that consists of inspecting data trafficked on computer networks, through the use of specific programs called sniffers
Unsolicited commercial e-mail. Term used to refer to unsolicited commercial e-mails
Unreliable connection used to control the management of applications at the service level between computers
Ultra-high frequency. Frequency range from 300 MHz to 3 GHz
A program or part of a malicious program designed to exploit an existing vulnerability in a computer program
Security holes that can be exploited by attackers
Security firewall that protects web applications from attacks and invasions
Wide area network. Computer network covering a wide area
Wireless Application Protocol. Global protocol used on many wireless systems, for users to view and interact with data services
Wired equivalent privacy. Security protocol for wireless networks which implements encryption for data transmission
Wireless network – Network that allows the connection between computers and other devices through the transmission and reception of radio signals
Wireless local area network. Type of network that uses highfrequency radio waves, instead of cables, for communication between computers
Standard of data transmission in packets
Zombie computer – Name given to a computer infected by bot, as it can be controlled remotely, without the knowledge of its owner
Zombie computer, infected by a bot
